title: Expanding College Student Mental Health With Stress Management Mobile Technologies - Extended Usability Trial
description_brief: This study is an 8-week usability and feasibility trial of the smartphone student stress-management app IntelliCare for college students. This intervention will be tested with University of Illinois at Chicago (UIC) and Northern Illinois University (NIU) students. During this period, research surveys assessing depression and anxiety can be completed on the app. Also, user feedback interviews will be conducted viatelephone at four weeks and at eight weeks to gain insight on the user experience of IntelliCare for College Students.
description_detailed: In this study, students will be recruited for an 8-week trial in which they will be given the IntelliCare Hub app and encouraged to use it daily. To ensure a sample representative of likely end users, 10 students from each site will be recruited: 5 with elevated distress as measured by scores \> 10 on either the PHQ-9 or GAD-7 and 5 without elevated scores on either measure, for a total of 20 participants. The rationale for 10 participants in each group is based on past usability research indicating saturation is typically reached within 10 participants. This trial aims to identify software bugs and usability problems that emerge over extended use and to examine preliminary effects of program use. During the trial, participants will be prompted to complete the PHQ-8 and GAD-7 every week. At baseline, 4 weeks, and 8 weeks, participants will be prompted within the app to complete the Depression Literacy Questionnaire and Anxiety Literacy Questionnaire to measure mental health literacy, the Knowledge and Beliefs about Services scale to measure knowledge of campus mental health services, the Barriers to Mental Health Help-Seeking questionnaire to measure treatment barriers, and the Cognitive and Behavioral Response to Stress Scale to measure cognitive and behavioral coping skills. At 4 and 8 weeks participants will be asked to participate in a user-feedback interview via the telephone. This is to gain insight on the user's experience with the app.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: One participant withdrew from the study after signing the consent form but before initiating any of the study activities, and we consented an additional participant in their place. A total of 21 participants consented.

groups.title: Extended Usability of a Mobile Self-help Intervention
groups.description:
Participants will have open access to the Intellicare Hub app for 8-weeks and be surveyed at Baseline, 4-weeks, and 8-weeks

Mobile self-help intervention: During the trial, participants will use Intellicare apps for up to 8 weeks and will be invited to provide feedback about their experience at two follow-up time points: weeks 4 and 8. All participants will first undergo initial assessments that will include a series of online questionnaires about their mood. Eligible participants will receive up to 8 weeks of access to the IntelliCare system, which consists of apps with a variety of resources, including lessons and tools designed to teach skills for mood management. It is suggested that participants utilize the mobile phone tools every day

achievements.comment: One participant withdrew after signing the consent but before initiating any study activities.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Patient Health Questionnaire - 8 (PHQ-8) - Depression Severity Module
measures.description:
The PHQ-8 measures degree of depression severity. Possible range of scores for the PHQ-8 is 0-24. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

Specifically, scores of 0-4 indicate minimal or no depression; 5-9 is mild; 10-14 is moderate; 15-19 is moderately severe; and 20-24 is severe.

For the subgroups presented, participants with a score less than 10 were in the "lower symptom" subgroup, and participants with a score greater than or equal to 10 were in the "higher symptom subgroup"

measures.title: GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale-7)
measures.description:
The GAD-7 is a self-administered 7 item instrument that uses DSM-V criteria for GAD (General Anxiety Disorder) to measure symptom severity. GAD-7 total score for the seven items ranges from 0 to 21. Higher values represent a worse outcome. Specifically, scores of 1-4 indicate minimal anxiety symptoms; 5-9 is mild anxiety symptoms; 10-14 is moderate anxiety symptoms; and 15-21 is severe anxiety symptoms.

Participants with a score \< 10 are in the "lower symptom" subgroup. Participants with a score greater than or equal to 10 are in the "higher symptom" subgroup.

measures.title: Anxiety Literacy Questionnaire
measures.description: This questionnaire is designed to assess anxiety specific mental health literacy by presenting 22 true or false statements regarding anxiety (e.g., "Being easily fatigued may be a symptom of anxiety disorder.") Participants receive a score of 1 for each statement they correctly assign as either true or false. Scores for each questionnaire can range from 0-22, with higher scores indicating greater anxiety specific mental health literacy.

measures.title: Depression Literacy Questionnaire
measures.description: This questionnaire is designed to assess depression specific mental health literacy by presenting 22 true or false statements regarding anxiety and depression (e.g., "Loss of confidence and poor self-esteem may be a symptom of depression.") Participants receive a score of 1 for each statement they correctly assign as either true or false. Scores for each questionnaire can range from 0-22, with higher scores indicating greater depression specific mental health literacy

measures.title: Cognitive and Behavioral Response to Stress Scale
measures.description: This is an 18-item scale designed to measure the use and helpfulness of cognitive and behavioral skills. There are four subscales: cognitive skill frequency, cognitive skill usefulness, behavioral skill frequency, and behavioral skill usefulness. For each skill, participants rate how often they used it and how helpful it was. Cognitive subscales scores range from 0-24, and scores from behavioral subscales can range from 0-30. Higher scores indicate better outcomes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Patient Health Questionnaire - 8 (PHQ-8) - Depression Severity Module
outcomeMeasures.description:
The PHQ-8 measures degree of depression severity. Possible range of scores for the PHQ-8 is 0-24. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

Specifically, scores of 0-4 indicate minimal or no depression; 5-9 is mild; 10-14 is moderate; 15-19 is moderately severe; and 20-24 is severe.

groups.title: Lower Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had PHQ-9 and GAD-7 scores under 10 at baseline

groups.title: Higher Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had a score of 10 or greater on the PHQ-9 of GAD-7 at baseline

outcomeMeasures.title: Patient Health Questionnaire - 8 (PHQ-8) - Depression Severity Module
outcomeMeasures.description:
The PHQ-8 measures degree of depression severity. Possible range of scores for the PHQ-9 is 0-24. Higher values represent a worse outcome.

Specifically, scores of 0-4 indicate minimal or no depression; 5-9 is mild; 10-14 is moderate; 15-19 is moderately severe; and 20-24 is severe.

groups.title: Lower Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had PHQ-9 and GAD-7 scores under 10 at baseline

groups.title: Higher Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had a score of 10 or greater on the PHQ-9 of GAD-7 at baseline

outcomeMeasures.title: GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale-7)
outcomeMeasures.description: The GAD-7 is a self-administered 7 item instrument that uses some of the DSM-V criteria for GAD (General Anxiety Disorder) to identify probable cases of GAD along with measuring anxiety symptom severity. GAD-7 total score for the seven items ranges from 0 to 21. Higher values represent a worse outcome. Specifically, scores of 1-4 indicate minimal anxiety symptoms; 5-9 is mild anxiety symptoms; 10-14 is moderate anxiety symptoms; and 15-21 is severe anxiety symptoms.

groups.title: Lower Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had PHQ-9 and GAD-7 scores under 10 at baseline

groups.title: Higher Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had a score of 10 or greater on the PHQ-9 of GAD-7 at baseline

outcomeMeasures.title: GAD-7 (Generalized Anxiety Disorder Scale-7)
outcomeMeasures.description: The GAD-7 is a self-administered 7 item instrument that uses some of the DSM-V criteria for GAD (General Anxiety Disorder) to identify probable cases of GAD along with measuring anxiety symptom severity. GAD-7 total score for the seven items ranges from 0 to 21. Higher values represent a worse outcome. Specifically, scores of 1-4 indicate minimal anxiety symptoms; 5-9 is mild anxiety symptoms; 10-14 is moderate anxiety symptoms; and 15-21 is severe anxiety symptoms.

groups.title: Lower Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had PHQ-9 and GAD-7 scores under 10 at baseline

groups.title: Higher Symptom
groups.description: Participants who had a score of 10 or greater on the PHQ-9 of GAD-7 at baseline

outcomeMeasures.title: Cognitive and Behavioral Response to Stress Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: This is an 18-item scale designed to measure the use and helpfulness of various cognitive and behavioral skills. There are four subscales included: cognitive skill frequency, cognitive skill usefulness, behavioral skill frequency, and behavioral skill usefulness. For each cognitive or behavioral skill, participants rate how often they used the skill and how helpful it was (e.g. "During the past month, how often did you take a moment to notice things that made you feel good or grateful? How helpful was this in making you feel better?"). Scores for cognitive subscales range from 0-24, and scores from behavioral subscales can range from 0-30. Higher scores indicate better outcomes.

groups.title: Extended Usability of a Mobile Self-help Intervention

Participants will have open access to the Intellicare Hub app for 8-weeks and be surveyed at Baseline, 4-weeks, and 8-weeks

All participants will first undergo initial assessments that will include a series of online questionnaires about their mood. Eligible participants will receive up to 8 weeks of access to the IntelliCare system, which consists of apps with a variety of resources, including lessons and tools designed to teach skills for mood management. It is suggested that participants utilize the mobile phone tools every day

outcomeMeasures.title: The Cognitive and Behavioral Response to Stress Scale
outcomeMeasures.description: This is an 18-item scale designed to measure the use and helpfulness of various cognitive and behavioral skills. There are four subscales included: cognitive skill frequency, cognitive skill usefulness, behavioral skill frequency, and behavioral skill usefulness. For each cognitive or behavioral skill, participants rate how often they used the skill and how helpful it was (e.g. "During the past month, how often did you take a moment to notice things that made you feel good or grateful? How helpful was this in making you feel better?"). Scores for cognitive subscales range from 0-24, and scores from behavioral subscales can range from 0-30. Higher scores indicate better outcomes.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention is a smartphone-based stress-management/mHealth program (IntelliCare for College Students) aimed at reducing stress, depression and anxiety and collecting symptom assessments — i.e., a behavioral/psychosocial treatment intended to improve psychiatric symptoms rather than a pharmacologic or disease-modifying therapy. citeturn0search4turn0search1

Act: Key details — intervention name: IntelliCare for College Students (smartphone app suite/hub delivering skills-based modules, symptom assessments, and user feedback interviews). This is not a biologic or small molecule drug; it is a digital mental-health intervention targeting depression/anxiety/stress, so it matches the 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' category. citeturn0search1turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — fits the provided category definitions: not a biologic, not a small molecule, not primarily a cognitive-enhancement drug, and explicitly targets psychiatric symptoms (depression/anxiety/stress). Therefore 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' is the appropriate category. No drug or placebo is involved. citeturn0search4turn0search7

Web search results (sources consulted): 1) PubMed entry for 'Examining an App-Based Mental Health Self-Care Program, IntelliCare for College Students' — describes an 8-week single-arm pilot with symptom assessments and user feedback interviews (JMIR Mental Health). citeturn0search4 2) Northwestern Scholars / JMIR description of the IntelliCare for College Students pilot (methods, outcomes, usability). citeturn0search1 3) IntelliCare suite description and prior trials showing reductions in depression and anxiety (IntelliCare apps, J Med Internet Res / Northwestern work). citeturn0search3turn0search7
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is a smartphone-based stress-management / mHealth program (IntelliCare for College Students) — a behavioral/psychosocial digital mental‑health intervention aimed at reducing stress, depression and anxiety rather than a biologic, small molecule, or mechanism-directed disease‑modifying therapy. This means there is no molecular or cellular CADRO drug target (e.g., amyloid, tau, inflammation) described. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Key details extracted — intervention name: IntelliCare for College Students (an app/hub delivering skills‑based modules, symptom assessments, and user feedback). It is not a drug, antibody, gene therapy, or pathway‑targeting agent; it targets psychiatric symptoms (stress/depression/anxiety) through behavioral techniques. Therefore it does not map to any CADRO mechanistic category A–S and should be classified as 'T) Other'. citeturn0search3turn0search2

Reflect: Confirming the choice — the trial tests usability and symptom outcomes for a digital psychosocial program (no molecular target, no drug). CADRO is organized around biological/drug targets; psychosocial/digital interventions that aim to improve neuropsychiatric symptoms but do not act on a defined biological target are best placed in 'T) Other'. No evidence in the cited sources indicates a biological mechanism that would map to a CADRO category. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Web search results consulted (for transparency): 1) PubMed entry for 'Examining an App‑Based Mental Health Self‑Care Program, IntelliCare for College Students' (JMIR Mental Health pilot describing the 8‑week usability study). citeturn0search0 2) JMIR Mental Health full paper describing methods, outcomes and usability of IntelliCare for College Students. citeturn0search1 3) JMIR 2017 paper describing the IntelliCare app suite (skills‑based apps and Hub). citeturn0search3 4) Northwestern Scholars / project summary describing IntelliCare outcomes and framework. citeturn0search2
